Hi all, 

I've been stuck with a problem, when i'm unit testing my code. 

=
My problem is that i've a really huge method,which calls several small
meth=
ods ( methods so small, they're just getters for member
variables), If i ha=
ve to unit test this method, i've to make sure all
the small methods that i=
t subsequently invoke, work as they're
expected. But all my member variable=
s get initialized seperately in a
different method which is of no relation =
with the BIG method I wanted
to test in the first place. 

Can I test my me=
thod without worrying about the initialization of my
object's data, by mock=
ing the results of all my getter methods ?  

Ex: 

Class MyClass
{
   priv=
ate Object _member; 
   public void initialize()
   {
     //huge initializ=
ation process, which initializes my member
variables. 
      _member =3D ne=
w Object(); 
   }

   public void myHugeMethod()
   {
       //.. my logic =
here.
       Object m =3D getMember(); 
       //... proceed with this valu=
e. 
   }

   public Object getMember()
   {
      return this._member; 
   =
}
}

Now, if I call 'myHugeMethod()' without calling 'initialize()' method,=

it always return NULL. 

All i wanted to do is to test 'myHugeMethod()', b=
y mocking
'getMember()' method and setting the result what i wanted. 

I tr=
ied using Jmock for creating mocks in my test case, but it fails
because th=
e mock object only knows what exactly I wanted to mock but
nothing more tha=
n that. All my application logic is present in
'MyClass' object not in its =
mock. 

How can I achieve this using Jmock ? 

FYI, I tried with a direct a=
pproach by extending 'MyClass' and
overriding the 'getMember()' method in i=
t. But I still feel there's a
better way to do it. 

I'll be very thankful =
for any help in this regard.. 

Thanks in advance, 
Sarat kumar.
